title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
Research interests
My research focuses in using computational approaches to better understand the role of the gut microbiome in human health. My three main research interests are:

Gut microbiome modulation of gut barrier integrity and its effects on host health
Expanding our understanding of the gut microbiome from underrepresented communities
Probiotic development

title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
About me
I finished my 4 years-long bachelor degree in biology at the Pontificia Universidad Catolica of Chile in 2019. During those years I volunteered at a laboratory working on the microbiome-gut-brain axis using D. melanogaster as an animal model. On 2020 I did an extra year of training that is mandatory to work in Chilean industries. It is during this period when I discover my love for computational biology, while I was involved in the characterization of new probiotics for the aquaculture industry. On 2021 I had a small detour working as a automation specialist at a Chilean company, where I developed python scripts to control a pipeting robot. On 2022 I joined the APC microbiome Ireland to work as a bioinformatician and in 2023 I started my PhD under the supervision of Professors John F. Cryan and Gerard Clarke.

title: The South American MicroBiome Archive (saMBA)
text:
The South American MicroBiome Archive (saMBA)
The South American Microbiome Archive (saMBA) is the largest archive of gut microbiome samples from South American populations analysed under an unified workflow. Note that while the workflow was deployed to build an archive of gut microbiome samples from South Americans, it can be used to build similar resources using samples from other bodysites or pupulations living in other neglected world regions. The motivation to start this project is described here.
The main outputs generated while building saMBA can be downloaded from this Zenodo repository. The analysis of those outputs is described in this preprint.


Plans for future developments
Below I share some ideas Iâ€™d like to implement to improve saMBA and to make it a useful resource for the entire community in the long run. I made this public to keep the users informed and to invite people interested in contributing in any of these points to reach out.


Build an R package to facilitate the download of the outputs in Zenodo
Implement the package using Snakemake and share it in Bioconda.
Expand saMBA (the resource) to include samples from other bodysites of southamericans.
Expand the workflow to include the analysis of projects using whole genome sequencing.
